 The practicality of Levels 3, 3A and 4 body armor are limited due to their weight and bulkiness, generally being limited to special forces rather than regular police officers. The majority of police officers only encounter suspects armed with handguns, so there's little call to equip them with 30 or 40 pound vests for patrol.

I wear level II armor for 12-14 hours while I work and don't really notice it. When we do tactical operations, we wear level III armor. It is difficult to actually wear level III vests for more than a couple hours, and it definately decreases your agility. 
 
 And guidlines stating what a vest will stop are very specific. They are determined not only by caliber, but powder load, structure and composition of the bullet, and velocity. A variation in any of these factors may not guarantee protection.

 Level III. It is not concealable. It is worn as a tactical vest that also holds our coms, emergency medical supplies, and other essential gear. 
 
 It is something similar to this (bottom vest) but at a threat level able to stop 7.62mm FMJ rounds (III). Our plates are not meant to shatter. They are meant to take several impacts at high velocity from rifle rounds in a short period of time and still provide protection.
